metadata.case_name: Appellant (Executive Engineer) v. State of Haryana/Government

facts.text: Appellant joined Punjab Irrigation Department as temporary Engineer in 1939 and became Executive Engineer.

In December 1954, appellant arrested in connection with case under Sec. 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act against K.R. Sharma, Superintending Engineer, with whom appellant worked as Personal Assistant; enlarged on bail.
Appellant suspended with effect from 13 December 1954; departmental proceedings started.

In November 1956, appellant served with charge sheet under Rule 7.2 of Punjab Civil Services (Punishment and Appeal) Rules, 1952, containing two charges (Charge 1a and Charge 1b) of taking illegal gratification.
On 18 December 1956, appellant submitted reply to charge sheet; added supplementary replies between May and July 1957.
Enquiry Officer appointed in October 1957.
On 18 February 1958, appellant reverted from Executive Engineer (under suspension) to Assistant Engineer (under suspension).
In May 1958, Government deferred enquiry on Charge 1b until decision on Charge 1a.
In October 1958, Enquiry Officer submitted report exonerating appellant completely on Charge 1a.
Government waited six months before appointing another Enquiry Officer for Charge 1b.
Appellant repeatedly asked for copy of first Enquiry Officer's report on Charge 1a; Government declined.
Criminal case against appellant ended in discharge in December 1960.
On 19 April 1961, appellant dismissed from service based on second Enquiry Officer's report on Charge 1b.
Dismissal order quashed by Punjab and Haryana High Court in March 1963; appellant reinstated and suspended again in May 1963.
Third Enquiry Officer appointed in May 1963 for fresh enquiry into Charge 1b.
In February 1965, appellant obtained civil decree for recovery of balance pay and allowances during suspension and quashing reversion order.
Between 1963 and 1965, appellant attempted through Establishment Board to close enquiry proceedings.
On 15 December 1965, new Enquiry Officer appointed replacing earlier one.
In January 1966, appellant reinstated as Executive Engineer.
In October 1966, entire enquiry against appellant withdrawn.
On 26 October 1966, Government served fresh Show Cause notice stating appellant's 18 December 1956 explanation unsatisfactory, proposing censure.
Appellant requested copy of S.D. Khanna's statement under Sec. 164 CrPC, as Charge 1b involved Khanna; also expecting it per High Court order but not received due to withdrawal.
On 24 November 1966, Government turned down request for Khanna's statement.
On 16 December 1966, appellant submitted reply to Show Cause notice.
On 27 February 1967, Government imposed penalty of censure.

On 27 February 1967, another order under Rule 7.3(3) of Punjab Civil Services Rules directing no payment beyond subsistence allowance for suspension period 31 May 1963 to 6 January 1966; period treated as duty for other purposes.
In June 1967, notice of compulsory retirement given, later withdrawn.
In October 1968, appellant compulsorily retired.
In November 1967, appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 challenging two orders of 27 February 1967.
Single Judge dismissed writ on 6 November 1968; Division Bench dismissed appeal in limine.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on 3 October 1969.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Show Cause notice dated 26 October 1966 was too vague to enable appellant to give effective reply, denying reasonable opportunity.
Whether the order dated 27 February 1967 withholding pay beyond subsistence allowance during suspension was passed without giving opportunity to represent.

petitioner_arguments.text: Show Cause notice dated 26 October 1966 too vague to enable effective reply as it did not specify which charges or parts of explanation were unsatisfactory.
Order withholding pay beyond subsistence allowance passed without opportunity to represent, violating natural justice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 7.3 Punjab Civil Services Rules; M. Gopala Krishna Naidu v. State of Madhya Pradesh

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant aware of charges and his reply, so notice sufficient; lenient censure proposed.
Appellant received reasonable opportunities earlier; order under Rule 7.3 consequential.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Distinguishing M. Gopala Krishna Naidu; State of Assam v. Raghava Rajagopalachari; Fundamental Rule 54

court_reasoning.text: Show Cause notice vague: did not specify which charge (1a or 1b) or which part of explanation unsatisfactory; no materials indicated; essential to specify scope and points for reply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice did not give real opportunity to defend; rejected State's argument that prior knowledge sufficed.

court_reasoning.text: Under Rule 7.3, authority must form opinion on full exoneration or unjustified suspension objectively, requiring opportunity to represent as it affects pay; principles of natural justice apply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant not fully exonerated on Charge 1b due to withdrawal; similar to M. Gopala Krishna Naidu; distinguished State of Assam case.

holdings.text: Show Cause notice too vague, denying reasonable opportunity; censure order invalid.
Order under Rule 7.3 invalid without opportunity to represent; must be objective consideration.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. Gopala Krishna Naidu v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Order under FR 54 (similar to Rule 7.3) requires opportunity to show cause as it is judicial function affecting pay.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Assam and Anr. v. Raghava Rajagopalachari
precedents_cited.relevance: FR 54(b) applies where not honourably acquitted; inapplicable as appellant not given chance for full exoneration due to withdrawal.

precedents_cited.citation: Decided by Supreme Court on 6 October 1967

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition filed under Art. 226 challenging orders.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Civil Services (Punishment and Appeal) Rules, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge sheet served under this rule.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Civil Services Rules, Volume 1, Part I
statutes_cited.relevance: Order on pay during suspension after reinstatement; requires opinion on exoneration and opportunity.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant sought copy of S.D. Khanna's statement.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds; High Court judgment and order set aside; orders dated 27 February 1967 quashed; appellant gets costs of appeal and below.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of censure order and pay withholding order.
outcome.costs: Appellant awarded costs of this appeal and costs incurred below.

key_quotes.text: "It is to our mind essential for a Show Cause notice to indicate the precise scope of the notice and also to indicate the points on which the officer concerned is expected to give a reply."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reason for invalidating censure order due to vagueness.

key_quotes.text: "The very nature of the function implies the duty to act judicially. In such a case if an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed is not afforded... the order is liable to be struck down as invalid on the ground that it is one in breach of the principles of natural justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applying principles of natural justice to Rule 7.3 order from precedent.

key_quotes.text: "Your explanation dated the 18th December, 1956, in reply to the statements of charges and allegations has been considered and found to be unsatisfactory."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Verbatim vague Show Cause notice held inadequate.
